ible or hardtop, a custom car or

dreds of language groups from
around the continents. Today
there are more persons speaking
English than ever before. 1t has
replaced French as the tongue Of
diplomats. | suppose it has prov
en- to be just as effective to con-
fuse your opponents or country
men In English as in French.


Living in the United States
gives one the rare opportunity
to hear, read and speak several
kinds of English. Being born in
the Midwest grew up in In
diana where the Hoosier twang
was familiar. We lived near a
family whose grandparents we're
from Syria. This gave me my
first hearing of this kind of
English with a Syrian flavor.


The neighborhood grocer was
a German Jew. His niece Molly
came from Europe to live with
him and | became her English
tutor. Molly spoke very little
English, but she soon surpassed
many native born. She had de-
lightful accent.


Americans in all geographical
locations have a local flavor to
their speech. In the hills or the
Blue Ridge or Ozark Mountains
some speak vague hill dialect.
Some of their phrases are trac-
ed TO colonial times.


Bostonians have long been the
favorite group who are teased
about their broad "a" sounds.
Few people realize they can slur
their sounds in a horrible man
ner, too.


New Workers. have different
boroughs and districts have made
history in novels and columns.
We know about Brooklyn and
Yonkers. The slang employed in
Harlem, where more Negroes
live in density than anywhere in
the nation, requires a new die
tionary.


Southwestern English tends TO
have the wide open space appeal.
The drawl is heard often and the
Mexican accents make English
have a spice.


Among men in the armed fore
es different types of language
are used. The navy. air force.
army. marines and even the acad-
emies offer new terms.


Occupation language is utilized
in the country. The medical pro-
fession, the automotive industry.
the lawyers. the bartenders and
the musicians have a lingo of
their own.


We laugh at some of the spoofs
made by comedians about our
language, but their jokes are
based on truth.


The Japanese and Chinese
manner of pronouncing some
words is no funnier than the way
some native Americans mispro-
nounce certain words.


| am anna ed that we are still
able TO meet on common ground
In the newspapers, movies, mag
azines and books to understand
a minute part of what is pro-
duced. There is one pet peeve
| have why don { radio and tel
evision news reporters use bet
ter ronunciation7 In an hour
you will hear more mispr onounc-
ed words than you could hear in
an characterization class of Kor-
cans.


Maybe each state tv-radio as
ISOLATION could sponsor a broad
cast refresher course for news
reporters. We cannot expect re-
porters to keep abreast of some
of the foreign names but they
